Climate change research is actually quite strong. It is not my line of research, but as an experienced scientist who has done a lot of refereeing of manuscripts, I can judge scientific research fairly well. You might not like the conclusion of anthropogenic global warming, but nearly every scientist in the world agrees that it is an obvious conclusion.

Sorry, you just failed the basic test of the scientific method, despite your "appeal to authority" logical fallacy.  The success of any theory is judged not by counting noses, but by its predictive power.   The predictions of CAGW (catastrophic anthropogenic global warming) are many -- and they are all wrong.  Every last one of them.

Fair enough. But first, learn what 'theory' means in science.
Then tell us all how the predictions have failed. It appears to most objective observers that the predictions have come true with a vengeance.
So give us some evidence to the contrary. I don't mean what you read on a blog, I mean solid evidence that we can all assess.

Go back and read the IPCC's first assessment report, in 1990.   Even though human emissions have dramatically exceeded their worst-case estimates, temperature increases have been far smaller than predicted.    Their predictions as to crop loss, drought increases, hurricane frequency increase, ocean rise acceleration -- all horribly wrong.     The fact remains that the planet IS warming -- but very, very slightly. And most of the effects of that warming will be positive, not negative.

You want me to go back to 1990, when accelerated global warming had only been confirmed in the early 1970s? Yes, they got some details wrong, but in principle they got most things right. So let's ignore the past 32 years of research. Models have become much more accurate, and Earth's warming is in the upper range of those models. Let's ignore that our planet is warmer and got warmer than in any other interstadial since the ice age began some 900,000 years ago. Let's ignore that CO2 levels topped out at 285 ppm in the previous three interstadials, and we are now at 419 ppm (with methane and other greenhouse gases up as well). Let's ignore that all of the top 10 warmest years in the historical record have been in this century, with the last decade far exceeding previous decades. Let's ignore the fact that sea level rise recently tripled from 1 mm per year to 3 mm per year, and with warmer temperatures on both poles, continental ice is melting faster so sea level rise will continue to accelerate.

As for the alleged rise of CO2 being "positive, not negative," that is but a joke. Any benefits for crop growth in the northern regions are far offset by increased desertification elsewhere. Meanwhile agriculture is suffering everywhere, but especially in Australia -- it is a smaller continent so the agricultural changes are felt more rapidly and profoundly than here in North America.

ROFL, they got it right "in principle"?  The entire concept of positive-feedback based accelerated warming has been disproven by the data.  Despite the fact that human carbon emissions are 4X higher than they were in 1960, and 10X higher than in 1920, the earth isn't warming any faster.   Hurricane frequency is decreasing, sea level is rising much slower than it was 5,000 years ago, and global crop production is at the highest point in human history by far.  The sky isn't falling, Chicken Little.

I'm sorry to be a heretic standing against your religion of global warming.  But facts are indeed just that -- facts.   A scientific theory is judged by its predictive ability.  Whether you look at the global warming predictions from 1982, 1992, or 2002, none of them have come to pass.

I tried to find out more, but I couldn't find anything beyond the NASA press release at this point. The technical document is probably still under peer review.

What I did find was that just like the standard mouse, there's the standard plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, basically broccoli's cousin. It been studied to death and there's even data about how it reacts in low gravity. You just don't go throwing some marigold seeds in there to see what happens.

They used soil samples from three different missions and volcanic ash as a control. None of the lunar samples did as well as the control and there were measurable differences in the soil from each mission.

Here's the interesting part - because they know so much about Arabiwhatever, they're able to sequence RNA from the test plants and match what they see with the existing data. Because their dataset is so extensive they can pinpoint the exact stressors causing the stunted grown, and that gives the direction for genetically modifying a plant that can deal with the conditions.

Actually those are different scientists who demonstrated by sequencing SARS-CoV-2 that it was of zoonotic origin. In other words, the coronavirus that causes Covid-19 originated in nature (no quotes needed.)
The genetic sequencing showed no such thing, and the research claiming such have been shown to be conflicted with special interest.  You're about 18 months out of date.  Do try to keep up.

The initial genetic sequencing by a multinational team and the conclusion of a zoonotic origin was initially questioned. That is good, as that is how science works.  But since the coronavirus and its variants have been sequenced by virologists/geneticists around the world with no special interests other than getting at the objective analysis of the origins of SARS-CoV-2. In September last year in the journal Cell, a metastudy of these publications concluded that the origin of of the coronavirus was zoonotic.
I just did a search of subsequent publications on the issue, and there have been no objections so far from the scientific community.

Do try to keep up. In the interim, please learn some basics about science.

Why do you liberals always believe it's ok to lie?  The metastudy in Cell did not "conclude" anything.  It stated that the "most parsimonious explanation" was a zoonotic transfer, but that, to quote, "the possibility of a laboratory accident cannot be dismissed, and may be near impossible to falsify".  In other words, they concluded we may never know with any certainty.
Maybe you should learn what "most parsimonious" means.

You lied, plain and simple.  It was a metastudy, yes -- but it did not 'conclude" that Covid was natural in origin.  It merely stated their belief that this was the "most likely" scenario, and specifically stated it could not rule out a lab leak origin.    Do you get it now, Cletus?

From the BBC:  "A classified US intelligence report [says] three researchers at the Wuhan laboratory were treated in hospital in November 2019, just before the virus began infecting humans in the city...."

Try to keep up.  In 2019, the PRC invokes emergency protocols, shuts down the Wuhan Virology lab, takes its DNA database offline, and installs entirely new safety measures.   A few weeks later, workers from the lab show up in local hospitals with severe Covid symptoms -- BEFORE the first case from this wet market ever appeared.   And immediately after the world discovers this information, China destroys every sample the lab possesses, which makes it impossible to ever determine exactly what they were working on, and when.

From what I've seen of your other posts on this article, you are in no position whatsoever to question the value of scientific research. Sprouting was the least interesting part of this research, though it showed that the moondust was not toxic to the germinating seeds. What was interesting was how the plants failed, and how they differed among samples from different sites on the moon.

Please do not confuse poor journalism with the actual science involved.

From what I've seen of your past posts, you should leave not only the science to others, but history, political, social, and military analysis as well.  We've known since the 1970s that moondust contains highly reactive compounds, which would need to be neutralized to act as an effective soil medium.  This "research" demonstrated no more than basic facts of biochemistry: roughly equivalent to a high school project demonstrating that adding fertilizer to plants allows them to grow better.

A seed won't germinate and grow in potash no matter how much you water it. Is lunar soil more like potash or styrofoam beads? A chemical analysis would give you the expected answer, but science doesn't accept the predicted answer until it's been tested. It's finding where the actual doesn't match the predicted that leads to figuring out how to make better predictions. The only way to find out - try it, ie. perform an experiment. One time in a million you don't get the expected result, but you have to go through the other 999,999 to find it.

I imagine that some of their excitement is due to just plain getting a result. After putting time and effort into something and having it come to a conclusion, whether the answer's boring or not, tends to make people happy.

Engineers and scientists get excited about things other people don't and vice versa. Throw a big company meeting to get spirits up for a major initiative and you'll have the folks in marketing, sales, etc. all hyped up while the engineers are wondering why their time is being wasted on such nonsense. Announce that everybody is getting another 8G of RAM in their computer and the engineers and scientist will be dancing in the hallways while the business team barely notices the announcement.
Very good explanation, thanks.

Point being, a seed needs moisture and acceptable temperature to germinate. It can grow without any sort of media covering it's roots whether it's soil or moon dust, or potash, (AKA hydroponics). Nutrients can be provided in the water they are supplied with. So unless potash damages the roots in some way or does something to prevent the water or the nutrients in the water from reaching the roots, a plant will grow in it. So what have they accomplished with this? They proved the lunar soil doesn't kill the seed.

I had a longer explanation somewhere else, but idea is basically this: They used a plant they have a lot of data on. After the plants grew they sequenced their RNA, and by matching it up with the data they already have they were able to pinpoint exactly which stressors are stunting the plants and what genes are involved. With that knowlege they can start genetically modify a plant that does well in that soil.

context:
It took real scientists and engineers to get us to the moon and back.

What passes today as science is puzzling.  There was a time when children learned about seeds, sprouting, and growing.  It was common knowledge that, if kept moist, seeds sprout, and grow.  It was also common knowledge that seeds planted in crushed gravel didn't do well.  Everyone knew the soil needed nutrients to foster growth.

There is no organic matter in crushed moon rocks.  A competent third grade science fair participant could have run circles around these geniuses.

context: A seed with germinate anywhere it receives sufficient quantities of water. Only after that does the soil need to contain sufficient nutrients for it to flourish.

replies.context: Out of curiosity, I read the original CB article to see what was exciting about germination. The article was primarily about how poorly they grew in a lunar regolith substrate, with no surprise about germination once water was added.

context: Everyone knows the moon is made of cheese...and that you can't grow spinach in cheese.

Germination requires water, oxygen, and the right temperature.  As long as those three things come together appropriate to the species, seed will germinate almost anywhere.  The scientist should not have been surprised that germination occurred.  If the seed had not germinated then there was likely something wrong with the seed or the conditions (water, oxygen, temperate) were not right.
Shouldn't the moon dust have high radiation from long exposure to the sun with no atmosphere? don't eat those mutant vegetables.

replies.context: No.  Do you even know how radiation works?

lol. apparently you do not. radiation levels on the Moon's surface are 200- to 1,000-times more than that on Earth's surface ‚Äì and 2.6-times more than what astronauts onboard the International Space Station (ISS) are exposed to.

Radiation levels being high has nothing to do with if the rock is radioactive itself but more to do with the amount of solar radiation that is present.  This just shows that having access to information does not necessary mean that you are able to properly use it or understand it.

So, in terms children can understand, no.  Moon dust (on Earth) does not have high radiation from long exposure to the Sun.  The material itself would need to be radioactive to retain radioactivity.
Thank you for explaining that so I didn't have to :D

Somebody came up with the idea of taking a portable x ray machine to places like nursing homes so they could take the x rays on site rather than transporting patients.

Well, I understand the abundance of caution the police displayed but that's hilarious.
